headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the beer demand side, I guess, short term, with now cycle COVID, maybe you could just give us an update on March depletion trends and what you're seeing in April so far? And then longer term, can you touch on the growth opportunity from here
componenttext:
Okay. So on the beer demand side, I guess, short term, with now cycle COVID, maybe you could just give us an update on March depletion trends and what you're seeing in April so far? 
And then longer term, can you touch on the growth opportunity from here on Modelo Especial? It seems to be defined the growth slowdown that happens to a lot of other brands as they get much larger. So it'd just be helpful to take a look forward at the key drivers from here in terms of incremental distribution expansion, innovation contribution, demographics, et cetera, some of the key drivers that happened in fiscal '21 and your thought process going forward in terms of the growth drivers for that brand?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We're very pleased to say that March has gotten off to an excellent start, and March was certainly ahead of what our trend line was coming in. So we're very pleased for the start of the new year. April, obviously, is a little early to judge.
componenttext:
Absolutely. We're very pleased to say that March has gotten off to an excellent start, and March was certainly ahead of what our trend line was coming in. So we're very pleased for the start of the new year. April, obviously, is a little early to judge.
Relative to Modelo, there's really no end in sight for its double-digit growth profile. It continues to grow with the Hispanic community. And obviously, there's a nice tailwind because of the growth in the Hispanic community. But we still have great distribution opportunities. We continue to grow our velocities on that brand. And when you think about the penetration increasing in the non-Hispanic community, 25% over the last couple of years, we're barely scratching the surface. 
As you probably know, we really only started to advertise outside the Hispanic community over the last few years. So the upside within that community, we think, is tremendous. And as you also know, we've really never done any innovation in that other than launching the Chelada line, which, of course, has quickly become the #1 Chelada. 
So the -- we think there's just a tremendous opportunity for Modelo to continue to grow for a long time to come. It's only #3 at this point. There's plenty of room still to go up.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kaumil Gajrawala with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kaumil Gajrawala with Credit Suisse.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: If I may just ask about buybacks, and you reiterated your $5 billion commitment, but it wasn't included in the release, I guess, in terms of what buybacks were going to be for fiscal '22. Can you just talk about how you're thinking about that?
componenttext: If I may just ask about buybacks, and you reiterated your $5 billion commitment, but it wasn't included in the release, I guess, in terms of what buybacks were going to be for fiscal '22. Can you just talk about how you're thinking about that?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Kaumil. So we're absolutely committed to meeting our $5 billion commitment over the course of the next 2 years. And as you know, that includes a significant amount of share repurchases, $2.5 billion worth of share repurchases. As we entere
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Kaumil. So we're absolutely committed to meeting our $5 billion commitment over the course of the next 2 years. And as you know, that includes a significant amount of share repurchases, $2.5 billion worth of share repurchases. 
As we entered this year, we said that we were going to have 2 real commitments as it relates to capital allocation. One was paying down debt and then second was making significant progress on that return of capital. Throughout the year, as we noted, we did pay down debt quite a bit. We started the year at about 3.92x and we're ending at about 3.1x. And we paid down -- the Gallo transaction closed in early January. We didn't pay down the last tranche of debt to $5 million redemption in early February. And at that point, we had some things that we were doing that we had to clear up, most notably, finalizing our analysis on Mexicali and then the subsequent further investment in capacity. So that's why we didn't make any progress in fiscal '21. But we fully expect to make meaningful progress this year.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: I guess, I had a question on your guidance. I understand the headwinds you guys called out that are going to pressure your beer operating income this year. But I guess, I'm trying to think through some of the levers you might have to offset these pressure
componenttext:
I guess, I had a question on your guidance. I understand the headwinds you guys called out that are going to pressure your beer operating income this year. But I guess, I'm trying to think through some of the levers you might have to offset these pressures. Beer pricing for one comes to mind. As you called out your pricing was softer last year, it was under 1% for the fiscal year, which is below your typical 1% to 2% range. So how should we think about your willingness to take more pricing this fiscal year to offset some of these incremental cost pressures? Would you be willing to go above your typical range?
And then finally, how much visibility do you have with some of the commodity and transportation headwinds that you're facing? Curious, are you fully hedged, for instance, on some of these commodities?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. Bonnie, why don't I take the first half of that. We believe the 1% to 2% pricing actions that we take pretty much on an annual basis is the smart way to approach it. It balances the opportunity to get improved revenue scenarios with the recognition
componenttext:
Sure. Bonnie, why don't I take the first half of that. We believe the 1% to 2% pricing actions that we take pretty much on an annual basis is the smart way to approach it. It balances the opportunity to get improved revenue scenarios with the recognition that you do have some price sensitivity within certain consumer groups that consume our brands. So you always walk that delicate balance of where you go. And our view is 1% to 2% is a good amount that allows us to continue to maintain the strong momentum within our business that we have. 
As you know, we continue also to aggressively increase our spend overall against our marketing platforms. And that will only be expanded when you think about some of the innovation agenda. So we're very optimistic about the whole platform, but getting much beyond that, I think, in any 1 year is probably not the best way to approach that question. And Garth, you might answer her second piece.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just on the opportunities and the hedging, Bonnie. So first of all, every year, our ops teams and our production teams are looking for ways to take costs out of the business. They'll continue to look for those as we go through the year. So those are
componenttext:
Sure. Just on the opportunities and the hedging, Bonnie. So first of all, every year, our ops teams and our production teams are looking for ways to take costs out of the business. They'll continue to look for those as we go through the year. So those are possible levers as we move forward. But quite candidly, those cost savings get harder and harder as time goes on. 
As it relates to our hedging position, as you know, we have a fairly robust and sophisticated hedging policy that allows us to layer in hedges on both commodities and on currencies over the course of many years to take advantage of favorable rates. That -- so we've done that in order to mitigate what otherwise may have been higher inflation this year. That being said, we are not fully hedged in any one thing, whether that's currency or commodities. And so to the extent that there are any improvements as rates, we could benefit from those as well.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: My question for you, just related to Mexicali. And I guess just trying to think through of the, I guess, roughly $800 million that was spent there, in terms of just cashback, are there -- what are the sort of opportunities to maybe recapture some of that
componenttext:
My question for you, just related to Mexicali. And I guess just trying to think through of the, I guess, roughly $800 million that was spent there, in terms of just cashback, are there -- what are the sort of opportunities to maybe recapture some of that cash? So whether it's repurposing the equipment, the land -- selling the land. 
Also, is there any -- will there be any cash tax benefit? Do you basically work that off as a loss and then there's a cash tax benefit? Just trying to understand how much of that cash we could think about you recouping over the next year or 2?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: So obviously, Bryan, we continue to work to mitigate that impairment. But obviously, we felt it was time to take that impairment. We have repurposed a number of the equipment things that we have there into other facilities as part of our expansion of the
componenttext:
So obviously, Bryan, we continue to work to mitigate that impairment. But obviously, we felt it was time to take that impairment. We have repurposed a number of the equipment things that we have there into other facilities as part of our expansion of the other facilities. And we're going to -- we're continuing discussions with the government as well relative to mitigating the impairment for the future as well. 
But I do think it's important to know one thing, though. We're not going to let this setback -- and admittedly, we're not happy about it. We're not going to let this get in the way of focusing on our growth and meeting the growth in high demand that we have for our brands over the long term. The reason we're doing the capacity expansion that Garth talked about previously is because our demand continues to be aggressive, a, on our core business, and b, we're going to get after the ABA/seltzer space in an even more aggressive way than we have up to this point. 
So we're not going to let this get in the way of us meeting consumer demand for our brands in the future. Garth, do you want to comment on the one?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just as it relates into further recovery. So first of all, the impairment kind of is net of what we think we've recovered to date, right? So we have been moving equipment out of Mexicali and over to Obregon in support of the 5 million hectoliters tha
componenttext:
Yes. Just as it relates into further recovery. So first of all, the impairment kind of is net of what we think we've recovered to date, right? So we have been moving equipment out of Mexicali and over to Obregon in support of the 5 million hectoliters that just went live. We continue to do that to support further expansion at Obregon and really taking the impairment is -- and making the decision to move on is the first step in further evaluating what our next options are, which, as you indicated, could include things like selling the land and whatnot. 
And then just further, as it relates to any -- the negotiation of the conversations, I should say, that Bill referenced, we do expect that there will be some additional recovery, and that recovery could come in many different forms. It could come in cash payments. It could come in tax credits. It could come into infrastructure credits, things of that nature. So we're certainly not done as it relates to trying to recover any lost cost.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vivien Azer with Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vivien Azer with Cowen.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: My question is on your beer margins, understanding that there are some very clear structural headwinds that you're contending with and aiming to offset with cost savings. I am a little bit surprised that your A&P guidance is not a little bit higher given
componenttext: My question is on your beer margins, understanding that there are some very clear structural headwinds that you're contending with and aiming to offset with cost savings. I am a little bit surprised that your A&P guidance is not a little bit higher given the substantial amount of new product activity. So I was hoping if you could just elaborate on kind of what informed the range and the order of magnitude, how you're thinking about prioritizing that spend?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: So I'm sorry, Vivien, I was trying to understand the question. So I think what I heard you say is you're asking the question around what's driving the -- or trying to get a sense for the scale of what's driving the margin dilution. So as we said, about
componenttext:
So I'm sorry, Vivien, I was trying to understand the question. So I think what I heard you say is you're asking the question around what's driving the -- or trying to get a sense for the scale of what's driving the margin dilution. 
So as we said, about 1/3 of the dilution is driven by the inflation, which we discussed. About 1/3 of that is coming from the increase in depreciation, and then 1/3 of that is from the mix impact moving towards seltzers and ABAs.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: And then do you want to answer why isn't advertising higher?
componenttext: And then do you want to answer why isn't advertising higher?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, advertising is going to be consistent going forward with what our historical trends have been in that sort of mid-9s range. We're obviously -- in a growth business like ours, that's still a significant increase year-on-year on what the total spend i
componenttext: Well, advertising is going to be consistent going forward with what our historical trends have been in that sort of mid-9s range. We're obviously -- in a growth business like ours, that's still a significant increase year-on-year on what the total spend is because it's coming off a very -- a much higher top line than it was in the prior year. So we're actually spending a lot more in our marketing spend than we had in prior years.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Great. I wanted to drill down on your views for the hard seltzer category, if I could. A 3-part question. So one, has the category slowdown that we're seeing in the Nielsen day in the first quarter. Is that in line with your expectations? Obviously, ver
componenttext:
Great. I wanted to drill down on your views for the hard seltzer category, if I could. A 3-part question. 
So one, has the category slowdown that we're seeing in the Nielsen day in the first quarter. Is that in line with your expectations? Obviously, very difficult year-over-year comparisons. But that being said, still moderating. 
Two, what are you forecasting for the seltzer category this year? What's embedded in your outlook? 
And then the last piece, just maybe touch on your level of satisfaction with your market share at this point. Understandably, you're leaning in now. You talked about the $60 million ad campaign. That being said, as we look at the Nielsen data, your market share is hovering in the 3% area. How is that relative to your expectations? Where do you expect that to go here over the next 12 months?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. 2 or 3 of those things, we'll try to get them all. It's not unexpected in a category that's continuing to bring in new consumers that you have some seasonality effect. We certainly saw a greater seasonality effect over this recent period than we saw
componenttext:
Sure. 2 or 3 of those things, we'll try to get them all. It's not unexpected in a category that's continuing to bring in new consumers that you have some seasonality effect. We certainly saw a greater seasonality effect over this recent period than we saw a year ago, as an example. Our view is that's likely because you have a significant higher percentage of either early or less consistent users. So it wasn't really a surprise. It still remains a growth sector within the beer industry. 
Our forecast is that it's going to continue to grow, and it's continuing to be a very important part, which is why we're more than doubling our capabilities against hard seltzer for this particular year coming that we're just starting. We believe this is going to be an important part, and it also provides an interesting entree for people into the overall beer category.
Relative to the market share. As you know, as we expanded our capabilities, that allowed us to do additional SKUs. We did almost 10 million cases this past year with 1 SKU, which is kind of an outstanding launch, if you will. But the expansion that we are putting in place is going to allow us to more than double that. We've already introduced SKU #2 and #2 Variety Pack, and we have Limonada coming online here this coming June. 
So our expectation is you'll see a significant increase in our share proposition, in part, because we'll have more available to the consumer, and we'll have more shelf space on the warm shelf and more cold box space in the cold box as well. So we're very optimistic about what our profile will look like as the year goes on.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Kevin, just to follow up on that really quickly. So the growth that you're seeing so far is fairly well in line with what we're expecting. We're expecting growth in the category this year to be in that 40% to 50% range.
componenttext: Yes. And Kevin, just to follow up on that really quickly. So the growth that you're seeing so far is fairly well in line with what we're expecting. We're expecting growth in the category this year to be in that 40% to 50% range.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sean King with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sean King with UBS.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: I guess, with your fiscal year ending, since then, it seems like the market opens up quite a bit. I guess, I'd love to know a bit more about what you're seeing in the on-premise. And also within that, have you seen any change in distributor inventory leve
componenttext: I guess, with your fiscal year ending, since then, it seems like the market opens up quite a bit. I guess, I'd love to know a bit more about what you're seeing in the on-premise. And also within that, have you seen any change in distributor inventory levels as more markets reopen?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. You are starting to see a difference, and obviously, it varies by state. So for instance, it got a little tighter in California in the early part of this calendar year than we had anticipated. But overall, we're starting to see some increase in the o
componenttext:
Yes. You are starting to see a difference, and obviously, it varies by state. So for instance, it got a little tighter in California in the early part of this calendar year than we had anticipated. But overall, we're starting to see some increase in the on-premise, as you would expect, recalling that sort of -- it's going against the time last year when it was off more than 50%. So we certainly would expect some of that. I think the open question it's very difficult to predict, quite frankly, is where the whole channel mix ends up going. It's an open question. 
As you know, we are somewhat less susceptible to the on-premise channel than some of our competitors because our overall profile skews more to the off-premise anyway. But certainly, we're optimistic. And as more of the U.S. population gets vaccinated, we're hopeful that in the summer months, it begins to look a little bit more like what a typical year would be. But it's still a little early to make that call.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Ottenstein with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Ottenstein with Evercore.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Great. Just 2 follow-ups, one for each of you. Bill, can you talk a little bit more about Pacifico? On every call, you get progressively more excited about it, which is great. Can you talk maybe sort of the reasons to believe that it's going to be a major
componenttext:
Great. Just 2 follow-ups, one for each of you. Bill, can you talk a little bit more about Pacifico? On every call, you get progressively more excited about it, which is great. Can you talk maybe sort of the reasons to believe that it's going to be a major national brand?
And then Garth, maybe touch on how you're thinking about the mix between share buybacks and dividends. It seems evident from the release, just a 1% dividend increase. Why so little? And is that just the way you're looking at things is that you'd much rather prefer share buybacks, particularly at the depressed valuation of the equity?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, Robert, Patty always warns me about being too giddy, but I must say it's tough not to be giddy when you look at some of the results around Pacifico. Consistently, you're seeing 4-week trends in IRI that are up in the 30-plus percent range. The cor
componenttext:
Well, Robert, Patty always warns me about being too giddy, but I must say it's tough not to be giddy when you look at some of the results around Pacifico. 
Consistently, you're seeing 4-week trends in IRI that are up in the 30-plus percent range. The core business in Southern California continues to do extremely well, and it's developing across the country. Again, we're really just scratching the surface of building out what this brand could be. 
But my old friend, Bill Hackett always said, Pacifico's starting to look a lot like Modelo look, about 15 to 20 years ago in terms of the development and how it really started out in the California base. As you know, Modelo is now the #1 brand in the state of California. I'm not making a prediction that Pacifico will be the #1 brand, but it wouldn't be the worst thing that ever happened. 
So certainly, there's just a lot to be excited about. You then add in that we're starting to do some innovation and some innovation testing in that brand with Gen Z consumers. This brand very much over-indexes with Gen Z consumers. So we're bringing in a somewhat different audience than what we have with some of our other franchises. So again, it's early days, but there's just so much to be excited about with Pacifico. We really think this could easily be the next big franchise within our overall portfolio. Garth, anything?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. And on the sort of capital allocation question regarding share buybacks and dividends. I mean, look, in the construct of everything we're trying to do from a capital allocation standpoint is we want to make sure that we maintain investment grade. We
componenttext:
Sure. And on the sort of capital allocation question regarding share buybacks and dividends. I mean, look, in the construct of everything we're trying to do from a capital allocation standpoint is we want to make sure that we maintain investment grade. We want to make sure that we return to shareholders what we previously said we would return to shareholders, which was about $2.5 billion of share buybacks and $2.5 billion of dividends. And we want to make sure that we have the flexibility to invest in our business. As we talked about, investing significantly in Mexico to support the robust growth of our portfolio. So all of that goes into the mix when we're trying to decide where to spend the money. 
And so -- and as it relates specifically to dividends versus share buybacks, we feel pretty good about where we are in terms of our payout ratio, right in the target of what we've set for ourselves. So that's why we didn't increase it more. And by keeping it where we are, we're able to do all those other things that I said: return a significant amount of money in share repurchases, invest behind the brands, maintain our investment-grade rating.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Carey with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Carey with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on a couple of the prior answers. I guess just one, I'm trying to understand what's embedded from an off-premise, on-premise standpoint for next year. It seems like if you get half of the on-premise back, you're looking for only
componenttext:
I just wanted to follow up on a couple of the prior answers. I guess just one, I'm trying to understand what's embedded from an off-premise, on-premise standpoint for next year. It seems like if you get half of the on-premise back, you're looking for only low to mid-single-digit in the off-premise. And if on-premise comes back in full, off-premise basically is implied to not grow next year. And I guess, what I'm trying to understand is, is that just a construct of difficult comps in the off-premise? Or is there something else at play because clearly, commentary from the trade seems positive. Nielsen scanner looks good even on COVID comps, again, innovation coming through. So I'm just trying to understand that. 
And if I could sneak one in, just on distributor inventory. You mentioned that inventory seems back to -- back at the levels where you want, but at the same time, the trade would suggest that you're still trying to catch up. So can you just add a little bit more perspective around that.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let's start with the inventory. Our inventory levels came out of last year at roughly a normal level. And we expect that it will stay roughly within that range. We have no major change in expectations about change in inventory.Relative to on-pr
componenttext:
Sure. So let's start with the inventory. Our inventory levels came out of last year at roughly a normal level. And we expect that it will stay roughly within that range. We have no major change in expectations about change in inventory.
Relative to on-premise, remember, today, it's only 6% of our business as it currently stands because of the significant decrease that's occurred based on COVID. So our expectation is we're still going to see very robust growth in the off-premise during this fiscal year. And as you've seen, we're consistent with our long-term growth algorithm that we've seen. Already stated, March is off to an excellent start. So we're very optimistic about that algorithm. 
But with that said, we -- it's also going to be difficult to exactly predict what will happen with the on-premise because we've already seen, as markets have opened and then closed a little bit and reopened, there's just a lot of variability that's hard to predict. 
Again, while there is an overexpression in the off-premise, that isn't the worst thing for us. Our business is over skewed into that area, and we continue to expect robust growth within the off-premise channel for this fiscal year.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Andrea Teixeira with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andrea Teixeira with JPMorgan.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I wanted to -- since we've covered a lot of ground in beer, a bit on wine and spirits. What are you seeing with the reopening? And also anything in terms of the switch between at-home and on-premises? Anything about promos and how you're going to
componenttext: Yes. So I wanted to -- since we've covered a lot of ground in beer, a bit on wine and spirits. What are you seeing with the reopening? And also anything in terms of the switch between at-home and on-premises? Anything about promos and how you're going to position your focus brand?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest switching that we've seen is a significant increase in 3-tier e-commerce. As we said in my prepared remarks, we were quite pleased with the fact that we got way ahead of that. We were already investing against that capability, and we've
componenttext:
Well, the biggest switching that we've seen is a significant increase in 3-tier e-commerce. As we said in my prepared remarks, we were quite pleased with the fact that we got way ahead of that. We were already investing against that capability, and we've accelerated that investment, which really, in our view, gives us a first-mover advantage in this particular area. 
And you are seeing that change. I'm sure just as a shopper, we've all seen in-store a significant increase of Instacart, Click and Collect and some of those. All are net ways of people buying, considering how they used to buy. 
Direct-to-consumer is also up. We're pleased that we are performing at more than 2x the growth profile of DTC. And we've also invested in that area. You'll recall earlier last fiscal year, we bought Empathy in part to radically improve our capabilities in the direct-to-consumer, and we are now leveraging that across many of our other brands. So we're very excited about those opportunities. And that being an increasingly important part of the future of the wine and spirits business

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Powers with DB.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Powers with DB.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to round out and build on the capacity expansion discussion you started earlier with Bryan. If I think just out beyond the fiscal '23 to '25 plans at Nava and Obregon, is it fair to assume that additional expansion would take shape outside thos
componenttext:
Maybe just to round out and build on the capacity expansion discussion you started earlier with Bryan. If I think just out beyond the fiscal '23 to '25 plans at Nava and Obregon, is it fair to assume that additional expansion would take shape outside those 2 facilities? Or is there more room to expand at those locations? 
And I guess, in terms of those new locations, Bill, I think you mentioned exploration of future sites in the southeastern part of Mexico, which I think is consistent with preferences that have been expressed by the Mexican government. But just can you elaborate on your considerations there because if that does play out, you'd be shipping long distance just to get to the southern border of the states and just thinking -- just want to think through how you're thinking about overcoming those dynamics just to preserve overall efficiency.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, let's put a little bow on the whole scenario about building out our capabilities. One of the things that we've been quite good at over the last several years is running our plants at hyper efficiency. But I think one thing is learning from the pande
componenttext:
Well, let's put a little bow on the whole scenario about building out our capabilities. One of the things that we've been quite good at over the last several years is running our plants at hyper efficiency. But I think one thing is learning from the pandemic, and I think if any good business should have an element of learning when something hits you in the face. And the pandemic certainly did that across many, many, many industries. 
One of the things we learned is while our efficiency was tremendous, we didn't have a lot of flexibility in the event that something didn't go well. And so one of the pieces that we are doing with this expansion is not only to meet the hyper growth that we have within our business, but also to create some increasing flexibility and some redundancy within our business. So then if you have weather challenges or, god forbid, we have another pandemic, but if you had weather challenges or some other curveballs that occurred, it would have minimal to no impact on our ongoing supply. So that was very important.
Relative to the Southeast, we are considering that. It's critically important to have water supply. There's actually a lot of shipping capabilities from some of the areas that we are looking into. So we're pretty confident that, that could very well be a future location for a brewery for us. Admittedly, that's a bit out. It takes 2 to 4 years to even get that process going and underway. But we're certainly evaluating it because we think it could be a long-term very viable solution for our business.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Laurent Grandet with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Laurent Grandet with Guggenheim.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'd like to actually follow up on Kevin's question on the seltzer category. So last year, when you launched Corona seltzer, you said you will spend about $40 million to introduce the brand.  So a year later, Corona seltzer is about 2.5% of market
componenttext:
Yes. So I'd like to actually follow up on Kevin's question on the seltzer category. So last year, when you launched Corona seltzer, you said you will spend about $40 million to introduce the brand.  So a year later, Corona seltzer is about 2.5% of market share in the last report with Nielsen and SCV is down 60%. 
So what makes you believe that with 2 new SKUs, 1 being launched late in the season just in June and spending about $50 million, which by the way, would be half your share of voice of last year, you would be more successful? And actually, what success would look like for you in fiscal year '22 in seltzer?

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let's keep in mind that $60 million, that will be the #1 share of voice in the seltzer category during the critical season. So our view is that's a very important and loud effort against that particular sector. Secondly, again, you got to ke
componenttext:
Sure. Well, let's keep in mind that $60 million, that will be the #1 share of voice in the seltzer category during the critical season. So our view is that's a very important and loud effort against that particular sector. 
Secondly, again, you got to keep in mind. We produced everything we could possibly produce at the volume -- last year, and we sold it. It was probably the most successful introduction the company has ever had with the Corona Hard Seltzer. So we were very pleased with our position. 
What we did see is there remained a lot of opportunity. It remains a growing sector in the beer business. We only had 1 SKU expanding our footprint to meet more consumer needs and occasions, and flavor profiles was going to be very important. And it also gives us the chance to get expanded reach and velocity at both at the warm shelf and in the cold box. 
So we think having the #1 share of voice in this particular category, coupled with our new introductions that are coming this year, we're very excited about what our share profile will look like as the year goes on.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021

componenttext: Thank you. I'm showing no further questions at this time. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Bill Newlands for closing remarks.

headline: Constellation Brands, Inc., Q4 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 08, 2021
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, and thank you all for joining the call today. I know it was a bit longer than some of them. As a result of our continued robust performance and financial discipline this past year, Constellation Brands achieved strong earnings growth,
componenttext:
Thanks very much, and thank you all for joining the call today. I know it was a bit longer than some of them. 
As a result of our continued robust performance and financial discipline this past year, Constellation Brands achieved strong earnings growth, generated record cash flow and significantly reduced our debt, providing solid momentum as we head into fiscal '22.
Our beer business has an exciting innovation lineup for the coming year, and we expect our core portfolio to continue to generate robust growth as well as we've talked earlier today. 
In order to satisfy this robust consumer demand, we have plans in place to execute our next increment of capacity expansion, and we are pleased to be in the position to continue investing in Mexico and enhancing our operational platform.
Our wine and spirits premiumization strategy gained significant traction during this past fiscal year and the divestiture of several lower-end wine brands positions this business for enhanced growth and profitability going forward.
We look forward to speaking with all of you again in late June when we will share the results of our first quarter of our new fiscal year. Before then, we hope you'll choose some of our fine products for your spring celebrations, including Cinco de Mayo and Memorial Day, and let us all hope they are a bit more normal. Thanks again, and have a great day.
